title: SEO and Meta
description: Improve your Nuxt app's SEO with powerful head config, composables and components.

children.value: Out-of-the-box, Nuxt provides sensible defaults, which you can override if needed.

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  title: 'My App',
  meta: [
    { name: 'description', content: 'My amazing site.' }
  ],
  bodyAttrs: {
    class: 'test'
  },
  script: [ { innerHTML: 'console.log(\'Hello world\')' } ]
})
</script>

children.value:
HTML element defines the document's title that is shown in a browser's title bar or a page's tab.
It only contains text; tags within the element are ignored.
element represents metadata that cannot be expressed in other HTML elements, like
HTML element is used to embed executable code or data; this is typically used to embed or refer to JavaScript code.
We recommend to take a look at the
composable lets you define your site's SEO meta tags as a flat object with full TypeScript support.
This helps you avoid typos and common mistakes, such as using

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useSeoMeta({
  title: 'My Amazing Site',
  ogTitle: 'My Amazing Site',
  description: 'This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.',
  ogDescription: 'This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.',
  ogImage: 'https://example.com/image.png',
  twitterCard: 'summary_large_image',
})
</script>

children.value: The title of your page without any branding such as your site name.

Use this tag to provide a short description of the page.
In some situations, this description is used in the snippet shown in search results.
This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.
A brief description of the content, usually between 2 and 4 sentences.
This is my amazing site, let me tell you all about it.
The URL of the image that appears when someone shares the content.
components so that you can interact directly with your metadata within your component's template.
Because these component names match native HTML elements, they must be capitalized in the template.
can accept nested meta tags (for aesthetic reasons) but this does not affect
the nested meta tags are rendered in the final HTML.

children.value: option to provide a dynamic template for customizing the title of your site. For example, you could add the name of your site to the title of every page.
can either be a string, where
is replaced with the title, or a function.
If you want to use a function (for full control), then this cannot be set in your
. It is recommended instead to set it within your
file where it will apply to all pages on your site:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  titleTemplate: (titleChunk) => {
    return titleChunk ? `${titleChunk} - Site Title` : 'Site Title';
  }
})
</script>

children.value: Generate the title from a template.
Now, if you set the title to
on another page of your site, the title would appear as 'My Page - Site Title' in the browser tab. You could also pass
option on applicable tags to append them to the end of the

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  script: [
    {
      src: 'https://third-party-script.com',
      // valid options are: 'head' | 'bodyClose' | 'bodyOpen'
      tagPosition: 'bodyClose'
    }
  ]
})
</script>

to set metadata based on the current route.
For example, you can first set the current page title (this is extracted at build time via a macro, so it can't be set dynamically):

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

children.value: And then in your layout file, you might use the route's metadata you have previously set:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const route = useRoute()

useHead({
  meta: [{ property: 'og:title', content: `App Name - ${route.meta.title}` }]
})
</script>

children.value: Returns the current route location. Equivalent to using

properties from all the matched route records.
is set either as a string with the
, which allows greater flexibility in setting the page title dynamically for each route of your Nuxt app:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  // as a string,
  // where `%s` is replaced with the title
  titleTemplate: '%s - Site Title',
})
</script>

children.value: // where `%s` is replaced with the title
Generate the title from a template.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  // or as a function
  titleTemplate: (productCategory) => {
    return productCategory
      ? `${productCategory} - Site Title`
      : 'Site Title'
  }
})
</script>

children.value: Generate the title from a template.
is also used as an alternative way of setting the page title. However,
does not allow the page title to be dynamic. Therefore, it is recommended to use
file to add a dynamic title, which is then applied to all routes of your Nuxt app.
The example below shows how you might enable Google Fonts using either the

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
useHead({
  link: [
    {
      rel: 'preconnect',
      href: 'https://fonts.googleapis.com'
    },
    {
      rel: 'stylesheet',
      href: 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Roboto&display=swap',
      crossorigin: ''
    }
  ]
})
</script>

children.value:
HTML element specifies relationships between the current document and an external resource.
This element is most commonly used to link to stylesheets, but is also used to establish site icons
(both "favicon" style icons and icons for the home screen and apps on mobile devices) among other things.
